name: NewYorker
text: James McBride’s novel, set in what appears to be a fictionalized version of the housing project where he grew up, is crowded with characters whose backstories are crowded with more characters, all of their fates connected. https://t.co/MBlIxNZOfd

text:

name: NewYorker
text: Ron Howard’s adaptation of “Hillbilly Elegy” evinces the same politically regressive ideas at the core of J.D. Vance’s memoir, @tnyfrontrow writes. https://t.co/oC7M5Nztq8

name: NewYorker
text: .@MiraPagliNair discusses her career as a filmmaker, the challenges of adapting a 1,400-page novel, and how rising intolerance in India affected her work on “A Suitable Boy.” https://t.co/X2zsMhdJnW

name: NewYorker
text: Can a vaccine be distributed fairly? What if a large number of people don't take it? @Atul_Gawande discusses the latest developments, and his concerns, on a new episode of our Politics and More podcast. Listen here. https://t.co/UWd2cClFhK

name: NewYorker
text: When he assumes office, Joe Biden will have to make up for President Trump’s failure to develop a true national strategy for getting supplies to hospitals, building a testing and contact-tracing system, and supporting health-care workers. https://t.co/d9NoPfzWjt

name: NewYorker
text: “ ‘Citizen Kane’ isn’t even Welles’s best film, and therefore can’t be the best film of all time,” @tnyfrontrow writes. “But why did it hold the title for so long?” https://t.co/GI88FTyvmE

name: NewYorker
text:
However constricted streaming may be, it lets the curious listener range across the musical map in a way that would be impossible under ordinary circumstances, @alexrossmusic writes.

name: NewYorker
text: “Maybe ‘A Teacher’ will stir awareness of the insidious patterns of abuse, but its storytelling doesn’t rise to the complexity of its subject matter,” @dstfelix writes. https://t.co/RGQ17UJFGw
